items.title: Examples in Manual reassigns Python keyword "input"
items.body:
Hi!
Love the pip package. I am finding it useful as a beginner in generating dynamic html with python. I just wanted to mention that in your example in the documentation you import as the following:

import dominate
**from dominate.tags import** *

However doing this reassigns the "input" python keyword. In other words after importing all (*) from dominate.tags globally in that module you can't use the input keyword. 

```
import dominate
from dominate.tags import *

var = input("Insert value: ")
print(var)
```

Example, the above code produces nothing.

I don't know if this was intentional but I don't believe it is the best way to showcase the features. 

Something like the following this might be better in the docs as an import block:

```
import dominate
import dominate.tags as dtags

dtags.a(href="somepage.html", etc)
```

Hi,
2.5.0 isn't on PyPI, can you please upload it there for consistency?

items.title: script with attribue 'async', 'defer'
items.body:
```
<script async defer 
          src="url"> </script>
```
I would like to render this code, but fail.

items.title: Unable to create custom tags containing hyphens instead of underscores
items.body:
In Python, classes cannot be creating with hyphens, and some front end frameworks such as Vue.js require them. 

See here:
https://vuetifyjs.com/en/getting-started/quick-start

This necessitates specifying a `tagname` attribute for each custom tag containing a hyphen, which is cumbersome and repetitive.

``` python
class v_app(vue_tag):
    tagname = 'v-app'

class v_content(vue_tag):
    tagname = 'v-content'

class v_container(vue_tag):
    tagname = 'v-container'

...
```

Perhaps the `html_tag` element could have a property such as `hyphenate_tagname` that would replace underscores with hyphens during rendering? Then the problem could be solved like so:

``` python
class vue_tag(html_tag):
    hyphenate_tagname = True

class v_app(vue_tag):
    pass

class v_content(vue_tag):
    pass

class v_container(vue_tag):
    pass

...
```

items.title: Underscores and aria-* tags
items.body:
Hello, 
All aria-* tags (used for bootstrap, for example) aren't converted when I write through named parameters where '-' are replaced by underscores. The only way I found is to use a dict and call it with **mydict
More generally, I have the problem with tags with dashes like 'data-page-size', the second dash wasn't converted.

Isn't there a bug?

Thanks

items.title: <main> semantic element missing
items.body:
Hey, the [`<main>`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/main) element cannot be used. When I run the following:

```python
doc.add(main())
```

I get: `NameError: name 'main' is not defined`

items.title: meta tag issues
items.body:
meta tag issues
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
_input_
with doc.head:
meta('content="text/html;charset=utf-8", http-equiv="Content-Type"')
meta('content="utf-8", http-equiv="encoding"')
_output_
<meta>
<meta>
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
_input_
with doc.head:
meta(raw('content="text/html;charset=utf-8" http-equiv="Content-Type"'))
meta(raw('content="utf-8" http-equiv="encoding"'))
_output_ 
<meta>
<meta>
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

items.title: Unable to insert raw div
items.body: I have a use case where I want to insert the output of plotly plot() function, but div() tag changes all < and > to &lt and &gt, which makes rendering that div impossible. I would like to be able to insert raw div tag without it being reformatted

items.title: example in package readme fails with traceback
items.body:
I tried the following (from the dominate package README) with Python 3.7.3 and dominate==2.3.5 in a virtual environment under OSX Mojave:

```python
    _html = html()
    _head, _body = _html.add(head(title('Whatever')), body())
    print(_html)
    names = ['header', 'content', 'footer']
    header, content, footer = _body.add(div(id=name) for name in names)
    print(_html)
```
and got the following output:
```
<html>
  <head>
    <title>Whatever</title>
  </head>
  <body></body>
</html>
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "scripts/alt_index.py", line 54, in <module>
    OPTIONAL_ARGUMENTS, POSITIONAL_ARGUMENTS, DEFAULT_LOG_LEVEL))
  File "scripts/alt_index.py", line 44, in main
    header, content, footer = _body.add(div(id=name) for name in names)
ValueError: not enough values to unpack (expected 3, got 0)
```

items.title: boolean attributes
items.body: It is not clear how one sets boolean (valueless) attributes, such as 'required' or 'autofocus'.  Neither the documentation nor the code seems to lend this information readily...?

items.title: lang tag in html ?
items.body:
I just started using your library and it is awesome. I think an ability to add `lang` tag inside an `<html>` would be really helpful for rendering a multi-languge html.

> According to the W3C recommendation you should declare the primary language for each Web page with the lang attribute inside the <html> tag, like this:
```
<html lang="en">
...
</html>
```

items.title: Context manager based tags are always appended
items.body:
Which can sometimes be confusing, depending on the source code: ``` from dominate.tags import * with div() as tree: with p() as first: first += 'first!' tree += p('second') print(tree) ``` produces ```

second

first!

``` Based on the code, one would expect first to come before second.

items.title: dominate.util.text not escaping new lines with
items.body:
If I add a text with `dominate.util.text()`, other characters as `<` and `>` are escaped correctly, except new lines which are not converted to `
`: ```python matched_text = "Escape-me\n" doc = dominate.tags.font( color=color ) with doc: dominate.util.text( matched_text ) ``` Results in: ```html Escape-me\n<please> ``` Then, I am not sure how to put new lines inside it without manually escaping the input text and putting it inside the document using `dominate.util.raw()`.

items.title: Why it is replacing my custom tag attribute underscore with a colon?
items.body:
If I render a code like:
```python
doc = dominate.tags.font( color=first_matched_color, grammar_scope=grammar_scope )

with doc:
    dominate.util.text( matched_text )
```
When it generates the html, the underscore _ on the name `grammar_scope` is replaced by a colon :
```html
<font color="#FF0000" grammar:scope="comment.start.sma">//</font>
```

items.title: Please add tags and update _version.py for recent PyPI releases
items.body:
Hi,
I noticed that 2.3.2 and 2.3.4 are not tagged on git and the `_version.py` file hasn't been updated either, can you fix this?

items.title: Create attributes without quotation marks
items.body: I want to create the following code: ``` import numpy import sys ``` for this I"m using: ``` doc = document() with doc: with tags.code('import numpy\nimport sys') as cc: cc['style']='display:block' cc['white_space']='pre_wrap' ``` it will create it as ``` import numpy import sys ``` And then the attributes are being ignored by my browser. PS: I'm a HTML noob, so there is surely a better way to do that.

items.title: Bug in a tag when using '&' char in the href url
items.body: When providing an url to the href attribute of an a node the '&' character is always escaped therefore modifying the url. As the '&' is commonly used to separate parameters in url this is quite problematic. Very simple to reproduce: ``` >>> from dominate.tags import a >>> test = a('toto', href='https://test.org/aaa?a=b&c=d') >>> test.render() 'toto' ``` Here we have a '&' instead of '&'. What would be expected is: ``` >>> from dominate.tags import a >>> test = a('toto', href='https://test.org/aaa?a=b&c=d') >>> test.render() 'toto' ``` Or am I missing something? BTW I tried to use `href=raw('https://test.org/aaa?a=b&c=d')` but with no luck (this was a desperate attempt).

items.title: Not really an issue. Unicode chars
items.body:
Hey, this is not really an issue, but i was wondering if you have anything built in or a way to handle unicode chars like `Malmö`. 

Depending on my use case, i am either getting a SyntaxError or a UnicodeEncodeError. Most of my functions return `str(object)` because i concatenate things later

And if there isnt something available to handle unicode, what would you say is the best way of handling these unicode chars?

Thanks!

items.body: as title. thanks

items.title: How can i write characters like > or " without it being html encoded
items.body: How can i write characters like > or " without it being html encoded. This is applicable mostly to script tags, but `"` is showing up as `&quot`. Example: `".context"`. Same applies with `>` which gets converted to `&gt`

items.title: [deleted]
items.body: [deleted]

items.title: How to show the special symbol?
items.body:
```
import dominate
from dominate.tags import *

doc = dominate.document(title='Dominate your HTML')

with doc.head:
    link(rel='stylesheet', href='style.css')
    script(type='text/javascript', src='script.js')

with doc:
    with div(id='header').add(ol()):
        p("I will display €")
        p("I will display √")

print(doc)
Html_file = open("test3.html", "w")
Html_file.write(str(doc))
Html_file.close()
```

items.title: How to use onclick method?
items.body:
```
import dominate
from dominate.tags import *
from dominate.util import text
doc = dominate.document(title='Dominate your HTML')

with doc.head:
    link(rel='stylesheet', href='responsive.css')  
    script(type='text/javascript', src='rbox.js')  

with doc:
    with p('You need to insert the ...'):
        text('[')
        # span('Click to Expand and see my code to insert',
        # title="Click to expand this topic or to contract a topic which has already been expanded",
        # cls="expand", onclick="return ExpandToggle(\'topic1\')")
        with span('Click to Expand and see my code to insert'):
            attr(title="Click to expand this topic or to contract a topic which has already been expanded")
            attr(cls="expand")
            attr(onclick="return ExpandToggle(\'topic1\')")
        text(' ]')
    with div(id="topic1", cls="expandedblock", style="display:none;"):
        p('The following is the code ...')

print(doc)
Html_file = open("test2.html", "w")
Html_file.write(str(doc))
Html_file.close()

```

items.title: Bug in html_tag._render() prevents easy generic tag class
items.body:
Hi, I need to create some html tags from input.  I don't know what they'll be in the code until runtime. 

I tried overriding the tag name, but there is a microbug that prevents it at:

https://github.com/Knio/dominate/blob/master/dominate/dom_tag.py#L317

I think the first variable t, was meant to be self.  There won't ever be an attribute tagname in a type.  When I change it to self, I'm able to override the tagname in a subclass:

```python
class tag(html_tag):

    def __init__(self, tagname, *args, **kwargs):
        self.tagname = tagname
        super().__init__(*args, **kwargs)
```

items.title: No way to override the title of an existing document
items.body:
The readme says:

> You should notice that here the `head` tag contains zero children. This is because the default `title` tag is only added when the document is rendered and the `head` element does not explicitly contain one.

That sounds like very useful behavior, but it doesn’t work — the default `title` is added eagerly. For example, this program:

```
import dominate, dominate.tags
doc = dominate.document()
print(repr(doc.head))
with doc.head:
    dominate.tags.title('Test')
print(doc.render())
```

prints:

```
<dominate.tags.head at 7f0ac5025ba8: 0 attributes, 1 child>
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <title>Dominate</title>
    <title>Test</title>
  </head>
  <body></body>
</html>
```

items.title: Provide a way of adding text nodes to the current context
items.body:
Currently, I have code like this: ``` def foo(): with dominate.tags.p(__pretty=False): bar() def bar(): if something: dominate.tags.a(u'this is a link', ...) else: dominate.tags.span(u'just some text') ``` This produces HTML like this: ```

just some text

``` Problem is, I don’t actually want that `span`, but I need it because there’s no other way to add a text node to the current context. I wish I had some equivalent `dominate.tags.text()`. I have enough of these placeholder spans that they make page rendering perceptibly slower.

items.title: Could not embed youtube video. Please update with this in your tags file.
items.body:
Youtube embedded videos require "<iframe width="560" frameborder="1" allowfullscreen></iframe>"

Since "frameborder" and "allowfullscreen" needed to be within the "<>", i had to add them to the global attributes as seen below. (This file can be found at Python\Lib\site-packages\dominate\tags.py)

_ATTR_GLOBAL = set([
  'accesskey', 'class', 'class', 'contenteditable', 'contextmenu', 'dir',
  'draggable', 'id', 'item', 'hidden', 'lang', 'itemprop', 'spellcheck',
  'style', 'subject', 'tabindex', 'title', **'frameborder', 'allowfullscreen'**

When you want to embed a youtube video you can now just use this format as an example:

iframe(width="560", height="315", src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Iqjy9UqKKuo", frameborder="0", allowfullscreen=True)

items.title: ENH: LinkedData
items.body:
Some of examples of building html containing linked data with dominate could be useful:
- [x] html5 data-key="value"
- [ ] HTML5  ( text/html; charset=utf-8 )
- [ ] XHTML + RDFa ( application/xhtml+xml )
- [ ] HTML5 + RDFa ( text/html; charset=utf-8 )
- [ ] HTML + JSONLD ( application/ld+json; charset=utf-8 )

References:
- https://wrdrd.com/docs/consulting/knowledge-engineering#rdfa #rdf #rdfs #schemaorg
- https://wrdrd.com/docs/consulting/knowledge-engineering#semantic-web-standards
- https://wrdrd.com/docs/consulting/knowledge-engineering#schemaorg
  - https://schema.org/
    - Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schema.org
    - Homepage: https://schema.org
    - Download: https://schema.org/version/latest/
    - Source: https://github.com/schemaorg/schemaorg
    - Source: https://github.com/schemaorg/schemaorg/tree/sdo-phobos/data/releases/2.2
    - Docs: http://dataliberate.com/2016/02/evolving-schema-org-in-practice-pt1-the-bits-and-pieces/
    - Issues: https://github.com/schemaorg/schemaorg/issues
    - IssueLabels: https://github.com/schemaorg/schemaorg/labels
